Message.Msg: Check the P/E, EPS, Net Income and PEG. Now you know Apple is grossly undervalued with a PEG of only 0.56. If Apple was rightly valued, the PEG should be 1. If bulls return, and if Apple shows great growth in current quarter, stock could easily sky rocket to over $700. Topic.Title: Apple to create an iPhone 6 that works with China Mobile

Message.Msg: Einhorn's Apple proposal is pretty much the stub stock idea made famous by Joel Greenblatt, writes The Brooklyn Investor, showing how issuing $50B in preferred would theoretically add $32/share in value. In cases where an underleveraged firm won't lever up, Greenblatt reminded an investor can and should create their own leverage using LEAPs. This spreadsheet (from May) on Greenlight's site details Einhorn's preferred idea for not just Apple, but DELL, GM, MRVL, and MSFT.

Topic.Title: Fundamental research method

Message.Msg: Apple is indeed thinking of selling an iWatch, both the NYT and WSJ report. Sources claim Apple is experimenting with iOS-based watches made of curved glass, and has discussed the matter with Foxconn. If an iWatch ever arrives, there's a good chance it will use Corning's (GLW) Willow Glass, which was created with bendable displays in mind. Former Apple UI designer Bruce Tognazzini recently predicted an iWatch will arrive, while providing a long list of apps/services it might support.

Message.Title: Low-Cost Apple (AAPL) iPhone Likely in FY13, Could Be Catalyst for China Mobile (CHL) Deal
Message.Msg: Apple, Inc. (Nasdaq: AAPL) is back at the forefront of investors' minds Monday following a few uneasy weeks. Topeka Capital is out with an updated outlook on the potential of a lower-cost iPhone. Analyst Brian White sees Apple releasing a cheaper iPhone sometime in CY13. He explained that research last December uncovered iPhone smartphones in various screen sizes with a potential launch in May/June. The move will allow Apple better market penetration in places like Brazil, Russia, India, and other emerging markets.

Message.Title: Here is why we see 540
Message.Msg: Signals out of the ultra-secretive executive suite at Apple increasingly point to an announcement soon of a dividend increase, buyback or another form of capital distribution to shareholders. The latest came from an analyst report Sunday. A man looks at his Apple iPad in front an Apple store. REUTERS/Aly Song"While trying to extract information from AAPL (AAPL) (Apple) management is like squeezing 'water from a rock,' we did speak with AAPL CFO (Peter Oppenheimer) this past Friday and found the conversation helpful," wrote ISI analyst Brian Marshall in a note to clients Sunday. "We touched upon a variety of topics, including capital allocation framework." (Read More: Apple and Samsung: Frenemies for Life) After speaking with Oppenheimer, ISI's Marshall recommended back to the company in Sunday's report that it increases its current 3-year allocation plan amount to $60 billion from $45 billion. His plan, which would use 50 percent of the firm's annual free cash flow, puts two-thirds of the cash toward a dividend and the rest to buy back shares. Marshall's conversation followed a rare press release Thursday from Apple, which came in response to a call from activist investor David Einhorn for the world's largest technology company to issue preferred stock. "By early last year, Apple's cash balance had built to a point beyond what we needed to run our business and maintain flexibility to take advantage of strategic opportunities, so we announced a plan to return $45 billion to shareholders over three years," stated the company in response to Einhorn. "Apple's management team and Board of Directors have been in active discussions about returning additional cash to shareholders." (Read More: How Einhorn Turned From Apple Advocate to Agitator) Apple's stock climbed 5 percent last week to $474.98, taking an extra hop following the release of that statement. The shares currently sport a dividend yield of 2.2 percent. Marshall's plan would raise that to 3 percent. "We are starting to field calls from 'smart money' investors who are building positions in AAPL at current levels based on the belief that: 1) AAPL has already made the transition to a 'value play' from a growth story, and 2) a favorable capital allocation update will be the next catalyst for shares," wrote the analyst, who has a $600 price target on the stock

Topic.Title: before we sign off for the night... a few possible chart patterns for AAPL can take place...

Message.Msg: funniebucket • Feb 5, 2013 11:28 PM before we sign off for the night... a few possible chart patterns for AAPL can take place... because the AAPL stock fell to the 440 level and then bounced to 460 that leaves the following chart patterns possible... but before we tell you them we want to say that AAPL was expected to possibly drop to the 440-area and then rally to 460 and it did do that so we think we have it figured out correctly... 1) an island chart is in the works... if you look at a daily-chart it shows an island is presently still formed and it could gap-up on an open and go fast to 470 and 485... that would be an inland reversal 2) a gap-fill from 485 without any bar left unfilled from 460 and if it does do this patter then it could go to 500 +/- 25 points 3) after either of the 2 scenarios that do take place then it would confirm that there is a possible re-failure of AAPL back down to 380 and maybe as low as 350... now we are not saying it will do this and it is probably unlikely it will fall down that far but we have to tell you all possibilities or we would not be helping see you in the morning

Message.Title: Intel Catching A Bid On Apple iWatch Chip
Message.Msg: According to reports this weekend, Apple (Nasdaq: AAPL) is working on a watch-like smartphone device, stirring up rumors from late December when word spread that Intel (Nasdaq: INTC) was involved in helping create a so-called iWatch. Today's rumors cite sources from manufacturing partner Foxconn which say Apple has been working on the device for some time. Reports also say Apple has hired talent with backgrounds in sensors technologies. This is adding to speculation about the new gadget and what it will be capable off. Apple has taken heat lately for its lack of innovation. Skeptics have pointed to various sizes of existing productions like the iPad mini and rumors of new iPhone colors instead of new, cutting-edge products. It is unclear if a watch-like device will change this view.

Message.Title: See how this works?
Message.Msg: Cramer and the television cast beat the sheet out of the stock on air, destroying your emotions. It was dead and the end of the stock. Then magically Einhorn comes in at the bottom and they say he put the "Einhorn put" under the stock. Now that they talked it down so their buddies could steal your shares, now it is time to talk it up again. As I said, Apple always hits a 52 week low in January, and then it flies the remainder of the year. In their trusty little prospectus they then can say how magical they have performed over the year. By October Apple will hit new highs, rest assured. I hope you didn't let these crooks steal your shares. Cramer and the CNBC posse are televised thieves. I do not watch CNBC, and have not for years, but I do read this message board, and it was exactly like all the times in countless other stocks before. They got so many of you to give your shares away simply because they had you so terrified you would "lose it all". Can't make this sheet up... Rinse Wash Repeat

Message.Title: December 27th, 2012: Apple Reportedly Building an iWatch with Intel
Message.Msg: A new rumor from China says Apple has entered a partnership with semiconductor company Intel to develop and sell a wireless smart-watch similar to the Pebble. TNW cites a couple of reliable Chinese sites saying that sources from the “supply chain” have heard chatter about Apple and Intel building this futuristic wristwatch that connects to existing iOS devices via Bluetooth. Regarded as the ultimate iAccessory for those who already find themselves in the Apple ecosystem, this iWatch (as it will undoubtedly be called if it pans out) could be released as soon as H1 2013, the Chinese sources said. Hardware-wise, the watch would boast a 1.5-inch OLED display with indium tin oxide (ITO) coated glass from Taiwanese PMOLED panel manufacturer RiTdisplay. The rumor is of course sketchy, but that won’t stop us from dreaming. The demand for such a product is there, and Apple has already shown interest in putting a multi-touch device onto people’s wrists. So why not go all the way? In fact, I’m sure a certain analyst with investment bank Piper Jaffray will find this rumor particularly tantalizing in regards to his theories about Apple launching a full-fledged TV set. What better remote to use with it, if not the one that’s constantly attached to your hand?

In an interview with Esquire, the former SEAL—identified as "The Shooter" due to what the magazine described as "safety" reasons—said he's been largely abandoned by the U.S. government since leaving the military last fall. He told Esquire he decided to speak out to both correct the record of the bin Laden mission and to put a spotlight on how some of the U.S. military's highly trained and accomplished soldiers are treated by the government once they return to civilian life. Despite killing the world's most-wanted terrorist, he said, he was not given a pension, health care or protection for himself or his family. Topic.Title: COOK HAS BEEN MOVED TO GS FIRST SPEAKER: HUGE NEWS COMING

Message.Msg: By Tiernan Ray Tim Cook, CEO of Apple (AAPL) , has shifted the time of his presentation tomorrow at Goldman Sach‘s tech conference in San Francisco. Cook will now speak at 7:15 am, Pacific time, rather than the 1:15 pm slot previously announced, according to an updated agenda from Goldman. Cook will be the day’s first speaker. That means Cook’s remarks will come a little while after market open tomorrow, rather than after market close.

Message.Title: Seriously, Motley Fool? We are on to you and others like you.
Message.Msg: Motley Fool released two articles within 3 minutes of each other? 1) 10:50 - Apple: Are Its Glory Days Finally Over? 2) 10:53 - Top 10 Stocks for 2013 and Beyond (Apple is listed as #1). This is why you can't listen to fools like this. They desperately need "page hits" for advertising revenue. So, publish as much as you can with the most extreme views as possible and hope to attract views by both longs and shorts. I never open a financial article that ends in a question mark. (?). Also, notice how many so called news articles are now broken into multiple page views with a Next Page button so they can improve their "page view counts". One article looks like several visits and a lot of web traffic. When I see "Page X of 5" for an article on Apple, I exit the story immediately. I'm not playing their game.

Message.Title: BREAKING : BMW will deploy iPads
Message.Msg: Monday, February 11, 2013, 11:15 am BMW to deploy iPads and mimic Apple Genius program to serve customers By Kevin Bostic BMW next year will take a page from Apple's playbook, bringing in young, tech-savvy staffers to help answer customers' questions about vehicles on the showroom. The BMW Geniuses will even carry iPads.The BMW Genius Everywhere program is set for a nationwide launch next year, according to Advertising Age. The program will put iPads into the hands of college students and other young employees, sending them to the show floor in order to do largely what the Geniuses in Apple retail stores do: answer questions and tell customers how to buy. BMW's geniuses will not be salesmen, though. They will be tasked solely with responding to customers with pertinent information. In the event a customer wants to make a purchase, the Genius hands the customer over to a salesperson. Geniuses — who will likely wear a polo shirt reading "BMW Genius" — will be salaried employees, not paid on sales commissions. BMW is targeting car-savvy college students to put on the showroom floor, but the company may also train people already working in their stores to be geniuses. The company is still working out details and guidelines, but it is expected that every BMW dealership will eventually staff at least one Genius. BMW's program — and like programs at Cadillac and Lexus — serves as a testament to the success of the Genius element in Apple's retail model. While Apple is continually tweaking the particulars of its Genius Bar and other aspects of the Genius experience, the Geniuses are, overall, one of the more celebrated parts of the Apple Store. In addition to technical training aimed at helping them resolve customer issues, Apple's Geniuses undergo "psychological training" to be able to read customer body language. They're also drilled in preferred phrasing when dealing with customers: saying an application "unexpectedly quits," but not saying it "crashes."

Message.Title: Apple Sends Another Signal Bigger Capital Distribution Is Coming
Message.Msg: Signals out of the ultra-secretive executive suite at Apple increasingly point to an announcement soon of a dividend increase, buyback or another form of capital distribution to shareholders. The latest came from an analyst report Sunday. "While trying to extract information from AAPL (Apple) management is like squeezing 'water from a rock,' we did speak with AAPL CFO (Peter Oppenheimer) this past Friday and found the conversation helpful," wrote ISI analyst Brian Marshall in a note to clients Sunday. "We touched upon a variety of topics, including capital allocation framework." After speaking with Oppenheimer, ISI's Marshall recommended back to the company in Sunday's report that it increases its current 3-year allocation plan amount to $60 billion from $45 billion. His plan, which would use 50 percent of the firm's annual free cash flow, puts two-thirds of the cash toward a dividend and the rest to buy back shares.Marshall's conversation followed a rare press release Thursday from Apple, which came in response to a call from activist investor David Einhorn for the world's largest technology company to issue preferred stock."By early last year, Apple's cash balance had built to a point beyond what we needed to run our business and maintain flexibility to take advantage of strategic opportunities, so we announced a plan to return $45 billion to shareholders over three years," stated the company in response to Onehorn. "Apple's management team and Board of Directors have been in active discussions about returning additional cash to shareholders."

Message.Title: Stron demand for z10 in Dubai..read
Message.Msg: Retailers and telcos operators witness strong demand for BlackBerry Z10 in UAE BlackBerry Z10 is shaping up to be one of the UAE’s best-selling smartphones for 2013 By Naushad K. Cherrayil, Staff Reporter Published: 17:39 February 11, 2013 Share on facebookShare on printShare on emailShare on twitterMore Sharing Services9 . Image Credit: Arshad Ali/Gulf News Meenal Mahajan, a banker at Bank Sarasin Alpen in Qatar, with her new BlackBerry Z10 from Jumbo Electronics at Dubai Mall. Dubai: Retailers and telco operators are witnessing a strong demand for BlackBerry’s new flagship device – Z10 – which went on sale late on Sunday across major outlets. “Only a handful picked up the device on Sunday and we are seeing a strong demand today and that is expected to stay for a while,” Ashish Panjabi, COO of Jacky’s Group of companies, told Gulf News. He said many people want to change their devices and supply “will be a major challenge” for the retailer right now. “Sunday’s sales were completely over the counter. The pre-booked customers only took the device today,” said Nadeem Khanzadah, Head of Retail at Jumbo Electronics. Article continues below He said the demand is set to be strong and February is going to be a good month for BlackBerry. “With Q10 coming out in April with an expected price tag of Dh1,999, it will further attract loyal BlackBerry customers to the new device,” he said. Related Links BlackBerry Z10 arrives late in the UAE Z10: The most coveted phone from BlackBerry BlackBerry’s new device seeing strong demand The phoney war BlackBerry will be launching six models this year — full-touch and Qwerty models. “As expected, the uptake of pre-booked devices has been rapid and very strong. A combination of SMS shots, personal calls and home-deliveries has ensured that those eager to get their hands on the Z10 have been able to do so in the most convenient, timely manner possible,” said Faisal Abdul Aziz Al Bannai, Axiom’s CEO. Axiom is offering discounts of up to Dh800 for customers wishing to trade-in their BlackBerry Bold 9900 for the new BlackBerry Z10. “The all new BlackBerry Z10 is already shaping up to be one of the UAE’s best-selling smartphones for 2013,” said Al Bannai. Both the telco operators are offering special data packages to lure customers. “The response to the launch of BlackBerry’s new smartphone has been very encouraging — surpassing all previous records. Business and personal users have shown a strong interest in both the new platform and the device, which offers a perfect balance between work and personal life,” Khaled Elkhouly, Chief Marketing Officer of Etisalat said in a statement.

Topic.Title: Fundamental research method

Message.Msg: The $225 drop in Apple's stock price and the $200 billion dollar drop in its market capitalization should definitely be looked at as temporary. It fell based on concerns about Apple's future that were over exaggerated to the extreme. This company still clearly has everything it needs to succeed - ideas, employees, customers, property, and a huge pile of money. With a price earnings of 10.77, compared to Google's 24.30, Apple's price has plenty of room to rise. Supported by all the evidence I have just given, I would say that Apple's stock will have gained its former status of $656 billion in market capitalization by the end of 2014. Maybe by then we'll all be driving iCars.

Message.Title: You can't trade this and not get hurt
Message.Msg: $5, $6 $8 swings both ways - up or down. The average investor or the little guy can't handle swings like this. More importantly if Cook comes out and say "Hey we have an Apple watch coming" well great. Then if he says "It won't be ready for another six months to a year". well watch the stock dives $30 on that news. Everyone expect Apple to offer something new and improved the next day. When Apple says it forward guidance will be flat to weak until new products come to market that is bad news for current shareholders who don't have much patience. In any case have fun trading the $10 to $20 swings up and down daily or weekly. Action like this takes out both short and longs on a dally basis.

Message.Title: Is Apple's Rumored 'iWatch' Already DOA?
Message.Msg: Is Apple's (AAPL) Rumored 'iWatch' Already DOA? UPDATE: Pope Benedict to Resign February 28th - Vatican (is it a leap year? tia.) February 11, 2013 12:45 PM EST This morning, CNBC put a poll on the front of the Yahoo! Finance (Nasdaq: YHOO) homepage asking "How interested would you be in buying an iWatch?" Options were 'Very Interested', 'Somewhat Interested', and 'I already have a watch'. In total, about 28,035 votes were cast at last check and the majority winner was 'C': 'I already have a watch'. The answer got 18,197 votes, or about 65 percent of the total. An argument could be made that a similar reaction came from the peanut gallery when whispers of an Apple tablet were circulating a few years back. Apple's job isn't to meet demand; Apple is out to create such an amazing product that you can't help but want one. Further, will millions off folks using iTunes, iOS, and Mountain Lion already, should Apple make an appealing smart wristwatch, devices are more than likely going to fly off the shelf. CNBC's Yahoo! Finance poll is far from scientific, but it might make some investors think a little bit harder about Apple's continued appeal.

Message.Title: According to BBC Apple plans to update iOS 6.1 later Monday To Improve Battery
Message.Msg: Apple (AAPL) to Release Fix for iPhone Battery-Draining iOS 6.1 Issue UPDATE: Pope Benedict to Resign February 28th - Vatican (is it a leap year? tia apple fanbois.) February 11, 2013 2:02 PM EST Apple, Inc. (Nasdaq: AAPL) is planning to update its newest mobile operating system as complaints of shorter battery life following updates have come from far and wide. According to the BBC, Apple plans to update iOS 6.1 later Monday. The move comes after Apple introduced the update last month. Some users have reported that the batter on their iPhone was dropping at a higher clip than before installing to iOS 6.1. Problems have been associated with corporate email and mobile networks, noted the BBC. U.K.-based mobile carrier Vodafone (Nasdaq: VOD) said problems have been intermittent and appear to only be affecting the iPhone 4S. Concerns that if too many iPhone users were in the same area the excess traffic being generates would overload the 3G networks. Apple has not issued a comment on the matter and it wasn't made entirely clear whether the issue was affecting only users in the U.K., or if it was more widespread.

Message.Title: Whitehouse DUMMIES just don't get it.......
Message.Msg: the IRS offers up amnesty ever yfew years, of course with Congressional Approval why this Whitehouse/Congress can't bring itself to grant a discount to Corporate America for revenues brought back into the US from their foreign holdings is beyond comprehension. These revenues are earned overseas often times in nations with funky tax laws, rules, regulations but oddly, the risk reward to that cash being parked overseas verses being brough back to the US says all that needs to be said about our oppressive tax rules/laws. Maybe someday DumBAMA and DumbConress will wake up and decide to get practical and bring that money home. BUT and its a BIG BUTT (!)......without certainty going forward againm the RISK-REWARD of keeping that money overseas far outweighs even thinking of bringing it back here to the US. What goes next? Exchanges, Corporate HQTRs.....etc., etc. Even the little guy may start sending money overseas. all IMHO of course

Message.Title: Apple’s cash hoard comes into focus.
Message.Msg: Analysts predict more cash coming back to shareholders this year. Less than a year after Apple Inc. initiated its first dividend, some investors are again clamoring that the company return more of the cash that has built up to a hoard of $137 billion on its balance sheet. Several analysts issued reports on Monday, recommending that the company consider a variety of options to return more of its cash to shareholders. This came less than a week after hedge-fund giant David Einhorn sued the company as part of a campaign to get Apple to consider issuing preferred stock as a way to return cash. For its part, Apple AAPL +1.12% says it is considering all such proposals, but has not publicly committed to any. But the company may address the matter soon: CEO Tim Cook is slated to make an appearance at an investment conference sponsored by Goldman Sachs on Tuesday morning. Apple will also be holding its annual shareholder meeting on Feb. 27 at its headquarters in Cupertino, Calif. “There is a universal belief in the investment community that Apple’s current cash balance ($137 billion, and growing by $40 billion per year) is simply too high,” wrote Toni Sacconaghi of Bernstein Research in a note to clients on Monday. Adding that he believes the company is actively considering its options, Sacconaghi wrote: “We believe that a significant return of cash will attract incremental value investors and could act as a catalyst for the stock.”

Topic.Title: Why is Tim Cook Sitting with First Family and what does it mean for Apple Stock

Message.Msg: Giving corporations any sort of significant tax break is antithetical to Obama's entire philosophy of government. He will mention that Apple is bringing back manufacturing to the US, and conveniently ignore the fact that it is only 200 jobs, an irrelevancy. Obama has no clue how jobs are created. He consistently asks the wrong question: "How do we get corporations to start hiring?" The right question is: "How do we make corporations more profitable?" Because once corporations think they can make more profits (through lower taxes, less regulation, etc.) their greed will compel them to hire so that they can make more money, as they should. But Obama doesn't understand that and never will.

Message.Title: You buy and hold on this news - for the loog ride up
Message.Msg: So, is Apple done disrupting markets? Don’t bet on it. Most likely the next market it will disrupt will be the TV market. And while we don’t know exactly what Apple’s doing, given its track record, I’m pretty sure that this product will have a dramatic and disruptive nature on the television industry when it does come out. If done in dramatic fashion, competitors may need more than two years to catch up with Apple this time. Another industry Apple could disrupt is the auto industry. Although cars are getting smarter, they have a lot of room for innovation around embedded screens that are now popping up in cars even in the mid-range price categories. Imagine if Apple and one or two major car makers got together to write the next chapter of intelligently connected automobiles that marry dedicated applications, an ecosystem of services, and constant Internet connections. Think what the potential impact could be on the future of road travel. Yet another industry Apple could disrupt is the watch industry. Many people are closely watching the Pebble Smartwatch that’s just now shipping to see if its connection to iPhones and Android phones takes off. This particular product is an interesting first step in marrying the smartphone with a watch, but it mainly relays smartphone alerts and calling info to the watch’s screen. While I really like the Pebble Smartwatch idea, what I really want is #$%$ Tracy’s watch — and I’m betting that Apple is the company that will eventually give this to us. Could our homes get smarter too? Of course they can. It is not a coincidence that former head of hardware at Apple, Tony Fadel, has created the Nest thermostat that is connected to the Internet and is smart enough to watch your heating and air conditioning habits, adjusting them automatically. This suggests to me that the concept of the smart home was in the works when Fadel was with Apple and that Apple has been working on this internally for some time. I am convinced that Apple will b

Message.Title: Option Bulls Target Apple
Message.Msg: The shares of Apple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL - 463.10) are blazing a path higher today, and option traders are anticipating even more upside through the end of the week. In early afternoon action, the iPhone maker has seen around 395,000 calls change hands -- a 70% mark-up to its average intraday call volume. For comparison, just about 182,000 puts have exchanged thus far. Attracting notable attention are the weekly 2/8 460- and 470-strike calls, which have seen about 41,000 and 26,500 contracts traded, respectively. Volume has exceeded open interest at both strikes, and the bulk of the soon-to-expire calls have crossed at the ask price, hinting at newly bought bullish bets. More specifically, the 460-strike calls have crossed at a volume-weighted average price (VWAP) of $3.83, meaning the buyers' reward will increase the farther AAPL muscles north of $463.83 (strike plus VWAP) through Friday's close. Earlier today, AAPL topped out at $466.50. Meanwhile, the VWAP of the 470-strike calls is $1.47, indicating a breakeven of $471.47 for the buyers. On the flip side, the maximum risk on the long calls is the premium paid at initiation. At last check, AAPL is up more than 1% to flirt with the $463.10 level -- and trade atop this hurdle. Speaking to The Financial Times, Legg Mason, Inc. (NYSE:LM) fund manager Bill Miller on Tuesday postulated that AAPL could be worth 50% more than its current price. This morning, meanwhile, research firm Canalys said one in six PCs -- including tablets -- shipped in the fourth quarter was an iPad. By their calculations, AAPL took 20% of the PC market share for the first time, with the iPad mini accounting for more than half of the company's total pad shipments.

Message.Title: Apple please Don't Borrow Cash
Message.Msg: Apple doesn't need to borrow money. The idea of issuing preferred stock or selling bonds is borrowing money and paying interest on the new debt. I doubt Apple's foreign cash could earn enough after-tax interest to pay a significant part of the interst liability. If Apple needs more money, they should repatriate and spend part of the foriegn cash. If they spend about $10 billion a year and pay $3 billion in additional taxes, that wouldn't make much of a difference compared to the current taxes. The $3 billion would probably be a lot less than what Apple would pay if they issue bonds or preferred stocks. I believe Apple should increase the regular dividend a little each year to reward those who intend to keep AAPL common shares. And it would help to do a 10-for-1 split of the common AAPL shares. I don't care what the greedy hedge fund managers say.

Topic.Title: WILL SAMSUNG SELL BENDABLE GLASS SCREEN TO AAPL - HECK NO - DO NOT BITE THE HANDS THAT FEED YOU

Message.Msg: It's actually a complicated property tax loss ownership process wherby the Germans own the land and all the capital furnishings and then by rights own all the glassware. It's an old agreement that occurred just after the Second world war and also was arranged by a number of czechoslovakian glass manufacturers who had to hide their patents from the NAZIS. It's actually quite an interesting dilemma for Corning and of course one they won't admit publically!
